newsitem.title: USA: Bills would let state take over Michigan schools.
newsitem.headline: Bills would let state take over Michigan schools.

text.p: Legislation introduced in the Michigan Legislature this week would allow the state to take over "educationally bankrupt" school districts.

The five-bill package introduced by State Sen. Dan DeGrow, R-Port Huron, would create a mechanism for state intervention in school districts that fail to meet minimum standards for educating students.

The legislation, which is supported by Gov. John Engler, gives the governor the power to declare a school district educationally bankrupt if 50 percent or more of students continuously score low on proficiency tests.

Once the declaration is made, the governor would then appoint a trustee to develop and implement a plan, make decisions over school spending and personnel and have authority to change or repeal district rules and regulations.
Meanwhile, the powers and duties of the school board and administration would be suspended under the legislation.
